qas.question: The Chinese government tried to tamper the boycott, trying to avoid a similar outcome to which protests in 2005?
Which newspaper urged citizens to protest peacefully?
Which website had mentions of the Carrefour boycott removed by the government?
When did protests in front of Carrefour's stores occur in China?
The Chinese government did not want a repeat of what protests?
Which newspaper asked the Chinese people to protest peacefully?
Who removed Carrefour boycott comments from some websites?
What day did protests occur in front of Carrefour stores?

context: In response to the demonstrations, <a6_0>the Chinese government<a6_0/> attempted to calm the situation, possibly fearing the protests may spiral out of control as has happened in recent years, including <a4_0>the <a0_0>anti-Japanese protests<a0_0/> in 2005.<a4_0/> State media and commentaries began to call for calm, such as an editorial in the <a1_0><a5_0>People's Daily<a5_0/><a1_0/> which urged Chinese people to "express [their] patriotic enthusiasm calmly and rationally, and express patriotic aspiration in an orderly and legal manner". The government also began to patrol and censor the internet forums such as <a2_0>Sohu.com<a2_0/>, with comments related to the Carrefour boycott removed. In the days prior to the planned boycott, evidence of efforts by Chinese authorities to choke the mass boycott's efforts online became even more evident, including barring searches of words related to the French protests, but protests broke out nonetheless in front of Carrefour's stores at Beijing, Changsha, Fuzhou and Shenyang on <a3_0><a7_0>May 1<a3_0/>.
